title: 103_s2479
content: The Act titled "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" aims to promote the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels. It includes an amendment regarding coastwise transportation of passengers. The Act "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation. It includes an amendment on coastwise passenger transportation requirements for vessels owned by US citizens and meeting specific criteria. A vessel under a demise charter with certain conditions is exempt from some ownership requirements. The Act "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation. It includes an amendment on coastwise passenger transportation requirements for vessels owned by US citizens and meeting specific criteria. A vessel under a demise charter with certain conditions is exempt from some ownership requirements, including a minimum 18-month term and approval from the Secretary for a 6-month extension after the charter ends. Additionally, a cruise vessel not documented under chapter 121 is exempt from certain regulations if it is to be reflagged. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation. An exemption is provided for a cruise vessel not documented under chapter 121 if it meets specific age criteria and the owner has entered into a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel in the US. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for an exemption for cruise vessels not documented under chapter 121 if certain conditions are met, including entering into a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel in the US. The authority to operate a vessel under this exemption terminates 18 months after the issuance of a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement if construction of another vessel has not commenced. The Secretary of Transportation may extend this period by up to 6 months. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for an exemption for cruise vessels not documented under chapter 121 if certain conditions are met, including entering into a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel in the US. The authority to operate a vessel under this exemption terminates 18 months after the issuance of a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement if construction of another vessel has not commenced. The Secretary of Transportation may extend this period by up to 6 months. A person operating a vessel in violation of this section is liable to the United States Government for a civil penalty of $1,000 for each passenger transported in violation of this section. The Secretary may issue a coastwise endorsement on the date; penalties include a $1,000 civil penalty per passenger for violations, vessel seizure for knowing violations, and disqualification from coastwise trade for non-compliance with construction contracts for cruise vessels. The coastwise trade regulations apply to cruise vessels over 10,000 gross tons with accommodations for at least 200 passengers. Penalties for non-compliance with construction contracts include fines and vessel seizure. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to deem certain vessels compliant with specific regulations and requirements for inspection and certification. This applies to vessels meeting standards for control verification certificates, having a coastwise endorsement issued after 1994, and being authorized for coastwise trade under relevant legislation. The Act of June 19, 1886 (24 Stat. 81, chapter 421; 46 App. U.S.C. 289) abolishes certain fees for official services to American vessels and amends laws related to shipping commissioners, seamen, and vessel owners. SEC. 5 amends the Shipping Act, 1916 regarding citizenship for vessel operation in passenger transport. SEC. 6 amends the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 by including passenger and cargo. SEC. 7 addresses permits for vessels entering national park units. The Secretary of the Interior has established a priority system for operating vessels in the National Park System. Priority is given to vessels documented in the U.S. or Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act, followed by foreign-documented vessels already permitted. Permits for foreign-documented vessels may be revoked or refused renewal. The Secretary of the Interior may revoke or refuse to renew permission for foreign-documented vessels to operate in National Park units if a person requests permission for a U.S.-documented vessel and there is a limit on permits. However, this restriction does not apply to persons holding rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. The Secretary of the Interior cannot revoke or refuse to renew permission for individuals with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act to provide visitor services in National Park units. Those whose permits are revoked have the right of first refusal for available permits in that unit.
